text:
East Houston Street, at, and adjoining the S.E. corner of Allen Street, showing a 2½-story frame house (at the corner) bearing No. 208 Allen Street. The 4-story house adjoining it is No. 173 East Houston Street. Both houses were later demolished for the widening of Allen Street, where a portion of the Second Ave. Elevated Line is conspicuously visible.

June 21, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

First Avenue and Allen Street, west side, south of East 1st Street, as viewed from the 2nd Avenue "El" platform. These two thoroughfares are continuous, with Houston Street the dividing line. Buildings on the right, between 1st and Houston Streets, are being razed preparatory to the 8th Avenue Subway construction. Subsequent to this, a playground will be constructed here. The photographer is viewing south westward from the north bound platform.

P. L. Sperr

February 17, 1928

1st Street, east from the Bowery, as photographed from under the Third Avenue "El". In the background, on First Avenue, is a station of the Second Avenue "El" Line. Between these two similar transportation features is Second Avenue. The three story curved corner building at the right was the infamous Suicide Hall. The owner was "Bloody" McGurk.

July 1928

George L. Balgue, photo

(1)
1st Street, west from but not including Essex Street, to and including First Ave. Also shown is First Ave., west side, north from and including East Houston, to and including 1st Streets. The view shows the Second Ave., Elevated Station on First Ave., and 1st Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date, but showing a closer and more extensive view of the north side of the street. Note the cleared area, between East 1st and East Houston (left, not seen) Streets after all the buildings were razed. The area was later developed as a park and children's playground. The demolition operations was needed to facilitate the construction of the Independent System (Eighth Ave.) Subway.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
1st Street, west from but not including Essex Street, to and including First Ave. Also shown is First Ave., west side, north from and including East Houston, to and including 1st Streets. The view shows the Second Ave., Elevated Station on First Ave., and 1st Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date, but showing a closer and more extensive view of the north side of the street. Note the cleared area, between East 1st and East Houston (left, not seen) Streets after all the buildings were razed. The area was later developed as a park and children's playground. The demolition operations was needed to facilitate the construction of the Independent System (Eighth Ave.) Subway.

P. L. Sperr.

154-156 (6-stories), and 158 (4-stories) East Houston Street, north side, west from First Ave., as seen from Eldridge Street. These houses constitute part of the entire block of buildings which were razed to facilitate the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. Subway), and upon whose site was later built a playground.
July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

186 (left, partly shown) to 194 East Houston Street, north side, east of First Ave., as seen from Orchard Street. These houses constitute part of an entire block of such buildings which were razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave.). Note the market scene which is typical of this area often
referred to as the "Jewish Ghetto."  July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A closer view of Nos. 190 and 192 East Houston Street, north side, at the foot of Orchard Street, showing the store fronts of two 4-story
buildings.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

186 (left, partly shown) to 194 East Houston Street, north side, east of First Ave., as seen from Orchard Street. These houses constitute part of an entire block of such buildings which were razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave.). (1)

212 and 214-218 East Houston Street, north side, between First Ave. and Ave. A, as seen from Ludlow Street.
July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date, after the demolition of the 6-story building, Nos. 214-218. The entire block of tenements, of which these were a part, were also razed to make room for the construction of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway). In the background is visible the steeple of St. Nicholas Catholic Church on East 2nd Street, between First Ave. and Ave. A.

December 21, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

212 and 214-218 East Houston Street, north side, between First Ave. and Ave. A, as seen from Ludlow Street.
July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date, after the demolition of the 6-story building, Nos. 214-218. The entire block of tenements, of which these were a part, were also razed to make room for the construction of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway). In the background is visible the steeple of St. Nicholas Catholic Church on East 2nd Street, between First Ave. and Ave. A.

December 21, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
98-84 1st Street, north side, east of First Avenue, also showing the building adjoining the corner. The view is from Essex Street looking northwest along the clearing for a curve of the Brooklyn line of the city-owned Eighth Avenue subway.
May 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, not showing 78-80 1st Street. The subway is completed, but has not been put into operation.
March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

1st Street, north side, at First Avenue, showing 1st Street station of Second Avenue elevated railroad.

May 9, 1930

P.L. Sperr

(1)
1st Street, north side, from First Avenue to a point just east of Second Avenue.
September 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a slightly earlier date, showing a more extensive view, to and including the Bowery. At the left appears East Houston Street, west from Eldridge Street. The cleared area, between 1st and East Houston Streets was created by the demolition of the buildings which formerly occupied the south side of the former and the east side of the latter streets, to facilitate the construction of the Independent System (Eighth Ave.) Subway.

P. L. Sperr.

June 6, 1930.

(1)
1st Street, north side, from First Avenue to a point just east of Second Avenue.
September 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a slightly earlier date, showing a more extensive view, to and including the Bowery. At the left appears East Houston Street, west from Eldridge Street. The cleared area, between 1st and East Houston Streets was created by the demolition of the buildings which formerly occupied the south side of the former and the east side of the latter streets, to facilitate the construction of the Independent System (Eighth Ave.) Subway.

P. L. Sperr.

June 6, 1930.

175 to 183 East Houston Street, south side, from Allen (right), east to Orchard Streets. In the foreground is shown construction work on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). Also visible (right) is Allen Street, east side, south from East Houston Street. No. 208 Allen Street, a 2 ½-story frame house that stood at this corner in 1927 is now gone. The adjoining building No. 173 East Houston Street was demolished at the same time; both as a part of the widening project of Allen Street.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

175 to 183 East Houston Street, south side, from Allen (right), east to Orchard Streets. In the foreground is shown construction work on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). Also visible (right) is Allen Street, east side, south from East Houston Street. No. 208 Allen Street, a 2 ½-story frame house that stood at this corner in 1927 is now gone. The adjoining building No. 173 East Houston Street was demolished at the same time; both as a part of the widening project of Allen Street.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

East Houston Street, south side, east from (No. 181), but not including Allen Street, showing under construction the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway), after houses between East 1st Street (left) and East Houston Street were razed.
June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view. On the left appears East 1st Street, south side, east from Allen Street.
June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

The same (at a slightly earlier date), viewed from a point somewhat eastward.
May 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
First Ave., east side, north from, but not including East Houston, to and including East 1st Streets. Note excavation work in progress for the Eighth Ave., Municipal Subway.

February 23, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing the curb side market at this point.

March 13, 1934.

June 26, 1936.

title: Manhattan: 1st Ave. - Houston E.

text:
First Avenue, east side, north from East Houston (extreme right and not seen), to E. 1st Street (buildings thereupon). At the latter point is the station of the Second Avenue Elevated Line running on 1st Avenue. Note the individuals retailing food stuffs and merchandise. These form a part of the overflow of the Orchard Street market. Behind the fence is equipment used for the Eighth Avenue Subway construction that passed beneath this spot and which necessitated demolition of the tenements that formerly stood here. Subsequently same will be cleared and a children's playground constructed. The buildings shown are on
the north side of E. 1st Street, east of the Avenue.

February 23, 1932.

P.L. Sperr

(1)
East Houston Street, north side, east from (No. 214), but not including First Ave. as seen from Ludlow Street. The block of houses, seen conspicuously, were later razed to make room for the construction
of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway).
July 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A detail of the same, showing prominently Nos. 222 to 230 East Houston Street, west of, adjoining and at the N.W. corner of Ave. "A." No. 230, the 5-story house at the corner also bears Nos. 1-3 Ave. A. Shown on the right is a clearance at the S.W. corner of Ludlow Street. These buildings were later demolished during the construction of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway) and today (1937) is a
playground.
March 13, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
East Houston Street, north side, east from (No. 214), but not including First Ave. as seen from Ludlow Street. The block of houses, seen conspicuously, were later razed to make room for the construction
of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway).
July 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A detail of the same, showing prominently Nos. 222 to 230 East Houston Street, west of, adjoining and at the N.W. corner of Ave. "A." No. 230, the 5-story house at the corner also bears Nos. 1-3 Ave. A. Shown on the right is a clearance at the S.W. corner of Ludlow Street. These buildings were later demolished during the construction of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway) and today (1937) is a
playground.
March 13, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

First Avenue, west side, from Houston to 1st Streets, at the beginning of First Avenue. The view is shut off by the 1st Street Elevated Station. There is a broad plaza here where 1st and Houston Streets come together; most of the old buildings were torn out around 1930 when a branch of the Eighth Avenue City Subway was dug under Houston Street.

June 25, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

First Avenue, east side, north from 58 First Avenue between 3rd and 4th Streets.

June 25, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

56-72 1st Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of First Avenue. March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

78 1st Street, adjoining the N.E. corner of First Avenue. April 28, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

88-78 1st Street, north side, east of First Avenue. Notice the date on No. 88.
March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Congregation Beth ha-Knesseth Anshei Podhaycer, 108 1st Street, north side, between First Avenue and Avenue A.
March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

East 1st Street, east from, but not including First Ave. The view shows a clearance for subway and park construction. Buildings shown on the extreme right, are on East Houston Street, south side, east of Orchard Street.

April 28, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) East Houston Street (where vehicles are seen) east from Allen Street, showing the clearance created between East Houston and East 1st Streets, by the demolition of tenements which faced on the north side of the former and the south side of the latter streets. Note construction going on for the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). Also shown (left) is East 1st Street, north side, east from (No. 84) but not including First Ave. The cleared area is now (1937) being utilized as a playground.

May 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date, as seen from First Ave. (a continuation of Allen Street), showing a portion of the Second Ave. Elevated Line on Allen Street.

March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) East Houston Street (where vehicles are seen) east from Allen Street, showing the clearance created between East Houston and East 1st Streets, by the demolition of tenements which faced on the north side of the former and the south side of the latter streets. Note construction going on for the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). Also shown (left) is East 1st Street, north side, east from (No. 84) but not including First Ave. The cleared area is now (1937) being utilized as a playground.

May 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date, as seen from First Ave. (a continuation of Allen Street), showing a portion of the Second Ave. Elevated Line on Allen Street.

March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
(1) Russian Bread kwas, made of honey and water; a Russian peasants drink, similar to our mead, being sold ice cold, at the corner of First Ave., and Houston Street. June 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same; another view, showing a street hawker, selling trousers. June 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A soft drink peddler on wheels; on York Ave., between 62nd and 63rd Streets. September 23, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Straw hats and food, being sold side by side, by peddlers along Houston Street and First Ave.
June 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Clothing - Hats and caps.

text:
Recreations and Hobbies: Italian individuals playing "Bocce" on East Houston Street near First Avenue. Tenements in the background are on the north side of E. 1st Street; the "El" line being on the avenue. This triangular play area was developed by the combined efforts of the Park Department and the W. P. A. on land remaining after subway construction underground.

1938-9

Alexander Alland
title: Recreation and hobbies - Bocci [game.]

text:

Views 1 and 2 are photographed southeastward from the downtown platform of the 2nd Avenue "El" line. View 3 is southwestward from the uptown side.

View 3: May 12, 1940
